The mathematical foundations of quantum theory have been a source of controversy for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory that is independent of any analytical structure. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results are also relevant to the foundations of quantum information theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we report the results of a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to replicate and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the design of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which is the most important adaptation strategy to mitigate the negative impacts of climate change on maize yields.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores (LMH) partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which LMH partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that LMH consumed a wide range of plant species, and that species were dissimilar in their diets. Nonetheless, species were not randomly distributed along a continuum of dietary similarity, suggesting that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which LMH partition food resources, and suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages. These findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in grassland ecosystems and biodiversity more generally.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are pessimistic about accessing the CARES Act loans.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and intriguing questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the formation of the solar system. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the motorized fleet could continue to increase in the coming decades, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In humans, the ability to produce offspring is a defining characteristic of the human species. In placental mammals, the ability to produce offspring is a defining characteristic of the mammalian species. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also a defining characteristic of the species of the placental mammal.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebral cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of mice with a model of MSA. This reduction in α-syn pathology was associated with a neuroprotective effect in the substantia nigra of the brain, as demonstrated by the preservation of tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is the first cell to come into contact with the blood and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is able to control the function of the blood vessels by integrating information from multiple sources. The information is integrated using a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that allows for rapid communication. The network is designed to be both local and global in its communication, allowing for rapid control of the blood vessels.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health researchers and policy makers. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including traditional public health surveillance data and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API is a resource that can be used to monitor the pandemic, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This finding has implications for the design of potassium channels as well as for the development of drugs that target these channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential of the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host, and the microbiome can influence the health of the host. This study provides evidence that anaerobic gut fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used as therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We found that high-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. The ability to design and manufacture complex mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for the development of functional devices. However, the design of such structures is often limited by the availability of materials and the knowledge of deformation mechanisms. Here, we propose a synthesis and fabrication strategy to design and manufacture complex mechanical structures with desired behaviors. The proposed strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are then assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture complex mechanical structures with desired behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, is expressed in the erythroid lineage and plays a role in the regulation of hemoglobin expression. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of hemoglobin expression in the adult erythroid lineage and that IGF2BP1 is a key factor in the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in the erythroid lineage toward a more fetal-like pattern. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a highly potent and specific form of cell death. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that this sensitizing effect is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor pathway, which is involved in the development of cardiovascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension in patients with advanced age or advanced cardiovascular remodeling. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and provided a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the proportion of older forests declined on federal land. The NWFP also failed to halt the decline of early-seral ecosystems on private industrial lands, where clearcutting continued. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. The problem is aggravated by the emergence of antibiotic resistance, which is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The presented approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other classes of antibiotics. This will help to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens and to address the problem of antibiotic resistance.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train than other popular architectures.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The shift in hydroclimate is consistent with a change in climate forcing, consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the Mid-Pleistocene Transition. The record provides evidence for a link between extreme hydroclimate variability and the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The mechanisms underlying the negative impact of electronic devices on sleep are not well understood, but the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices may be a key factor. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin secretion and reduces the timing of the circadian clock, and that this effect is associated with reduced sleepiness and reduced alertness the next morning. These results demonstrate the importance of understanding the impact of electronic devices on sleep and health. They also highlight the need for further research to understand the impact of these devices on performance and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is a key event in the Earth’s history, and it is widely accepted that a bolide impact triggered the YDB. However, the bolide impact hypothesis is challenged by the lack of evidence for a bolide impact in the YDB deposits. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules in YDB deposits is consistent with terrestrial sources, and the spherules in the YDB deposits are consistent with their source being from a meteorite impact. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is not limited to the development of autoimmunity, but also in the development of tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant tissues, such as leaves, stems, and wood.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural ecologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to expectations, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, it is the variation in plane performance that is enhanced by larger populations, and that this variation is critical to the process of innovation and adaptation.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the APOE ε4 allele. However, the mechanism by which APOE influences AD risk is not known. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles influence the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may be the mechanism by which APOE4 increases AD risk. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is testable and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key part of the Earth's interior, but its formation mechanism is still poorly understood. The inner core is likely to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a key factor in understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. They also provide a new perspective on the nucleation of other materials. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana addiction. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

The human brain’s language comprehension system is the most studied cognitive skill in neuroscience. However, the system’s underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models can predict the brain’s responses to spoken sentences in humans. This suggests that the system’s computational mechanisms may be general and widely distributed across the brain. We also find that model architecture is strongly associated with neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They have implications for the design of artificial intelligence and for understanding the neural basis of human language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not well-conditioned. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are well-conditioned and prove that they can compute stable neural networks. This opens the door to understanding the stability of DL and to designing better algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of exponential growth. The exponential growth rate is the key to understanding the pandemic’s dynamics. The classic experiment used to study the growth rate is often cited as a proof of the exponential nature of the pandemic. However, the experiment’s design is flawed, and the conclusion is wrong. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still a major public health problem in the developing world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and is now a small, highly conserved organism. In contrast, the pathogen associated with the least severe form of the disease, diffuse lepromatous leprosy, is a larger, more diverse organism that has retained many genes required to infect the nervous system. These findings suggest that the two leprosy pathogens have been evolving together for millions of years, and that the differences between them are the result of divergent selection.

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum systems is a fundamental open problem. We show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which may be difficult to obtain for the general population. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is easy to produce and can be administered as a single dose. This vaccine is highly attenuated, which may reduce the risk of severe COVID-19.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was the most devastating epidemic in human history, leading to the death of 30–60% of the European population. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. However, this hypothesis is challenged by the fact that rats were not present in Europe at the time. Here, we show that human fleas were the primary vector of the disease during the Second Pandemic, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the history of plague and the development of vector control measures.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the number of neurons, has been neglected. This study fills this gap by reconstructing the evolution of brain size by neuron number. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. The evolution of brain size is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are dynamically disassembled and reassembled by a family of proteins. These proteins are the central regulators of actin filament disassembly. We show that the action of these proteins is enhanced by mechanical stress. We also show that the action of these proteins is enhanced by mechanical stress.

The consumption of fructose, a common sugar found in many processed foods, has been linked to weight gain. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically compared with those of glucose, a common sugar found in many fruits. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be greater than previously thought. They also highlight the importance of the context in which fructose is consumed, as the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be attenuated in the presence of a meal. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and for the development of effective interventions to reduce fructose consumption.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a major finding because it suggests that people are not just influenced by the emotions of others, but also influence the emotions of others. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of emotions, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been difficult to study. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the A site of the bacterial ribosome can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence, and that this effect can be observed in human cells. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have a significant impact on translation, and that this impact may be more widespread than previously appreciated. This work provides a foundation for future studies to understand the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, sex, and educational attainment. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of larger body sizes is unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of rhinovirus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature has been a puzzle. We show that the mouse airway cell model recapitulates the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus in primary cells, and we demonstrate that the innate immune response of infected cells is more efficient at 37 °C than at 33 °C. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and suggest that the ability of rhinovirus to replicate more efficiently at cool temperatures may be a key factor in the emergence of new rhinovirus strains. Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced virulence and biofilm-inducing genes, and is required for the long-term attachment of the bacterium to surfaces. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its impact on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. Our results suggest that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into wildlife and the reemergence of the virus. Here, we report the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the subsequent discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the urgent need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that are needed to move toward sustainable hydropower.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the source of this inflammation is still unclear, with the most common hypothesis being that it is triggered by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary driver of the earliest inflammatory response in the brain, which occurs in the absence of plaques and cell death. We demonstrate that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory molecules, and that the extent of this response correlates with the vulnerability of the region to AD pathology. Thus, we propose that the accumulation of soluble Aβ in neurons is the primary cause of the AD-associated inflammation, and that this process may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of the disease.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most successful examples of human-animal cooperation. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is, however, still elusive. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. This finding has important implications for the study of the domestication of the chicken, as well as for the study of the early history of the domestic fowl in Europe.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The folding of a single protein is a complex process that involves many steps and many intermediates. The folding of a single protein is also a collective process, in which the folding of one part of the protein affects the folding of other parts. The collective nature of protein folding makes it difficult to study, and it is difficult to obtain a complete picture of the folding process. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a single protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results indicate that the intermediates are obligatory steps on the folding pathway and that the intermediates are not the end of the folding process. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for the rapid degradation of the transcripts. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the caps is not the one that is inactivated by the stress conditions that enable accumulation of the caps, but rather a different enzyme that recognizes capped 5′ ends in a manner distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This enzyme, which we name RNA pyrophosphohydrolase, is able to deprotect capped 5′ termini at a much higher rate than its counterpart, and it is the primary enzyme responsible for the rapid degradation of capped transcripts in response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of action is the production of proinflammatory cytokines. The immune system is also responsible for the resolution of inflammation, which is a process that is impaired in sepsis. This study shows that arginine, a precursor of proinflammatory cytokines, is the main mediator of the resolution of inflammation in sepsis. This study also shows that arginine can be replaced by citrulline, which is a precursor of antiinflammatory molecules, and that this replacement can restore the resolution of inflammation in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a more complete census of the biomass of wild mammals. This work is a step toward a global census of the biomass of all taxa.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit with a unique fixed point. This is in contrast to all known models of SOC, which are discrete. The model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, which limit its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. It also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work can help to advance the development of diamond-based devices.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a major area of research in the field of protein science. The structure of the 36-amino acid NCR044 peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy. This unique structure was largely disordered and highly dynamic with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The antifungal activity of the peptide was also characterized. The results show that the peptide is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and the mode of action is unique. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This study is a good example of how the structure of a protein can be used to understand its function. It also illustrates the power of NMR spectroscopy in the study of peptides.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that female-derived proteins play a critical role in supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and demonstrates that female-derived proteins play a critical role in supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. This work provides a foundation for future studies that will elucidate the extent of intersexual continuity in the male–female reproductive axis. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is the first time that such a conversion has been observed for a protein. The results provide a general mechanism for understanding the effects of force on proteins. They also provide a platform for studying the effects of mutations on the protein’s function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately linked to human health. The viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 2,200 strong virus–disease associations. The database is freely available to the scientific community, and can be used to study the impact of the virome on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI, which is difficult to be observed and measured. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The most widely accepted interpretation is that the surface cooled from ∼70 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite is able to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and establish a blood-stage infection. The invasion process is a complex event, involving a number of parasite proteins, and the identity of the receptor-binding proteins on the parasite and the receptor on the host cell is well established. However, the function of the interaction between the malaria parasite and the host cell receptor is unknown. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, which may be important for invasion. This study provides a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This may have implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and disease outcome. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain performs this operation is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Activity in superior temporal and inferior frontal regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. It is important for the formation of the gut, the formation of the placenta, and the maintenance of the immune system. The pathway is also important for the development of the nervous system. The pathway is also important for the maintenance of the immune system. The pathway is also important for the development of the immune system. The pathway is also important for the development of the immune system.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra (SN), as well as by dopamine neurons in the LH. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of dopamine neurons in the LH, the VTA, or the SN. Finally, we show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH GABA neurons that project to the VTA, and that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for future studies of the role of dopamine in the regulation of feeding.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is essential for the growth of all terrestrial life. However, the amount of N2 fixed by the atmosphere is vastly outweighed by the amount fixed by the few N2-fixing bacteria that colonize the roots of these plants. Thus, the development of a synthetic plant-controlled N2-fixing symbiosis would represent a major advance in the field of synthetic biology. Here, we describe the development of a rhizopine-based synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows for the control of N2-fixing bacteria in association with the plant. This system represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled N2-fixing symbiosis.

The Amazon is the world’s largest tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unclear. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed deforestation alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of auditory organs, but they are all made of tissue and are part of the body. We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is not only extremely sensitive to sound, but it also has the ability to sense the direction and location of sound. This allows the spider to hear without a body, and it also enables the spider to hear without a head.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than those of reducing greenhouse gases. This is because air pollution is a major contributor to the global warming, and the cooling effect of aerosols is masked by the warming effect of air pollution. Our results suggest that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 1.5 million lives worldwide and continues to cause severe illness and death. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This variant is amenable to inclusion in a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD variant may be a useful tool for vaccine development and other applications.

The role of the ALK oncogene in human cancer is well established. However, the function of the ALK family of tyrosine kinases in development is less clear. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We demonstrate that the zebrafish ALK homologs are able to activate the human and the mouse ALK homologs in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide evidence that the ALK family of receptors is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This finding is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK family receptors in human cancer. Furthermore, it opens the way for the development of zebrafish models for the study of ALK family receptor function in development.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the cause of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time and place of its origin have been debated for decades. We present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its emergence. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a direct descendant of a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor, but rather a result of a series of evolutionary steps. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of the global food system. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to massive losses of SOC to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reversing these trends is unknown. We show that the management of perennial pastures with rotational grazing can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the more stable mineral-associated fraction on Mollisols. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on agricultural landscapes worldwide. This study also highlights the importance of soil health management practices in the context of climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to rank the spillover potential of 887 novel viruses from animals. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of this trait in Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species. Our findings provide evidence for the importance of this trait in plant–pollinator interactions and suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also highlights the potential for the discovery of new bioactive compounds.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 600 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals in our sample is very heterogeneous, and that the genetic diversity of the women in our sample is particularly high. In addition, we find that some of the women had skull deformations that were probably corrected by the removal of the bones’ innards. Our results suggest that the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results also establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and the transmission of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also suggest a potential strategy for the prevention of cross-species transmission of bat coronaviruses to humans. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs against M

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogen(s) causing undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early deployment of public health response. We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and cost-effective approach for the identification of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for the implementation of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The results of this study will help to inform the development of a national mNGS platform for the surveillance of undifferentiated febrile illness in Cambodia.

The lagging strand of the double helix is replicated in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the synthesis of the lagging strand, but the mechanism by which this stability is achieved is unknown. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the mechanism of DNA replication in eukaryotes. It also provides a platform for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the first experimental reconstruction of an RNA world in the laboratory. We show that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA molecules, amplify them by PCR, and synthesize functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This work represents a major step toward the experimental reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life. It also provides a platform for the study of the origin of life and the evolution of life’s biochemical machinery.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is a great challenge. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab may be a potential treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in this process is less clear. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. These metabolites have significant metal-dependent antimicrobial properties, and the ability of xan cluster metabolites to bind copper is supported by the observation that copper-dependent inhibition of laccase activity is observed in a xanthocillin-treated Pseudomonas aeruginosa culture. These results suggest a role for fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with other microbes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present day temperature of the Red Planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a diagenetic product. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with the presence of tridymite in the Martian mantle, and the presence of tridymite in the Martian mantle is consistent with the presence of tridymite in the Martian crust.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly linked to the evolutionary history of the species, and that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the local frost risk. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management and forestry practices to the changing frost risk, and to develop frost insurance policies. They also provide a framework for understanding the impact of frost events on other temperate and boreal species, such as animals and crops.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of Th17 cells lacking the IL-17A effector gene, suggesting that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Th17 cells were also required for the development of colitis-associated autoimmunity, indicating that they are important for the development of pathogenic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and provide insight into the mechanisms by which these cells contribute to the development of autoimmunity. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the cause of the disease is unknown in most cases. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will greatly advance ALS research and accelerate the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the insect microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the pathogen. We demonstrate that the ability of antifreeze glycoprotein to alter the composition of the gut microbiota is due to its ability to bind the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector and have implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals on Earth, and the study of their evolution is a central topic in paleontology. The evolution of the tail and the loss of the tail are two of the most important morphological changes in the evolution of birds. This study describes a new early bird from the Early Cretaceous of China, which adds to our understanding of the evolution of the tail and the loss of the tail in birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. The most common color polymorphism is the presence of red and blue colors in the same animal. This color polymorphism is called dichromatism. The most common dichromatism is the presence of red and blue colors in the same animal. However, there are also animals that have only one color, but can change it. This phenomenon is called dichroism. The most common dichroism is the presence of green color in the animal. This phenomenon is called dichromatism. This study shows that the presence of green color in the animal is not a coincidence, but is the result of a biochemical mechanism.

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is critical for the development of metastases and the resistance to therapy. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) residues on mRNA. We show that ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which are responsible for the initiation of metastases. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, and instead found that the source of the parchment was consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that the production of ultrafine parchment did not necessarily require the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is controversial, but the timing of the event is well constrained by the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model for the extinction and recovery is less certain, and the role of the carbon cycle in the extinction and recovery is poorly understood. This paper provides a detailed age model for the extinction and recovery, and demonstrates that the carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction and recovery. This work will improve our understanding of the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery. (Show more)

The nuclear receptor retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is involved in a variety of biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study reveals that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. Our findings also provide insights into the role of RORα in the intestine. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that are currently circulating in the United Kingdom and the United States.
