We find that the variant with the D614G substitution has a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for fusion. This may explain the higher transmissibility of this variant.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
Simplified version: We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, and the Latino−White gap will decrease by more than 3 y. These results highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 and other health disparities.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the properties of compounds. The chemical properties of atoms are also the key to understanding the origin of the chemical phenomena that occur under pressure. Here, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, as a function of pressure, are consistent with the emergence of exotic chemical phenomena under pressure. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the emergence of exotic chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions and suppression is unclear. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by increasing greenhouse gases. This is most effective under lower emission scenarios, highlighting the importance of human activities in driving fire regimes. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks may be able to mitigate some of the warming caused by human activities, but that this is contingent on continued reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which animals regulate the activities of their microbial partners are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We demonstrate that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation, and that its catabolism is specifically required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. These findings suggest that animals may regulate the activities of their microbial partners through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions in the habitat of the symbiont. This may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbioses.

The study of topics in text data is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and capitalizes on the strengths of topic modeling and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, was introduced into Europe in the 14th century. This event marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe is generally understood as the result of a single event, which led to the establishment of the disease in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the introduction of Y. pestis into European harbors was preceded by climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into Asian harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human societies. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a valuable food resource for a variety of marine animals, including sea otters, sea lions, and humans. However, asteroids are also a major source of mortality for a number of marine animals, including sea otters, sea lions, and sea stars. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroids) on the Pacific coast of North America.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show here that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in the metabolism of glycerol. We found that the protein interferes with the action of the RNA, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This study provides insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs and the mechanisms by which they compete with each other. It also provides a mechanism for the action of a small RNA that has been shown to repress two genes. This mechanism may be relevant to other sRNAs that repress multiple genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is statistically robust and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the design of large-scale continuous monitoring systems for agriculture, and for the development of new indices for monitoring the health of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the sustained activation of neurons. However, alternative mechanisms have been proposed, such as the facilitation of synapses. Here we propose a different approach to memory in the brain, where information is stored in the dynamics of the neuron itself. We show that the activity of individual neurons can be used to encode information, and that this information can be accessed later. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The release of carbon dioxide from soil is a major yet poorly understood flux in the global carbon cycle. This process is hypothesized to increase with rising temperatures, potentially fueling further increases in global temperatures. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it occurred in the past, and the evidence is indirect. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is linked to the evolution of relaxed purifying selection in the plastid genome. We demonstrate that the relaxation of selection is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Our findings suggest that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a stepwise process, in which the parasite’s dependence on a host gradually replaces photosynthesis as the main selection pressure on the plastid genome. This process is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. This may have facilitated the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus and the emergence of the first eukaryotes. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent droughts in SSA. It also provides a useful tool for risk assessment and adaptation planning. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. We report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the formation of this material and the date of the explosion.

The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common autoimmune disease of the CNS. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation in the central nervous system. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be promising therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the interaction of multiple genetic variants and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms and suggests a potential therapeutic target for autism. (Show more)

The news media are often accused of being negative, but it is difficult to know whether this is true because of the difficulty of measuring the content of news. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the content of news in a way that has not been done before. The results show that, on average, news is predominantly negative, but that there is considerable individual-level variation in the extent to which people react to this content. This variation is likely to be important for understanding the spread of news around the world, and for understanding the psychology of news consumption more generally.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the CRAC channel pore (ORAI1) or sense changes in the concentration of Ca2+ in the endoplasmic reticulum (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, that are consistent with a role for store-operated Ca2+ entry in the pathogenesis of these conditions. Our findings suggest that modulation of store-operated Ca2+ entry may be a potential therapeutic target in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by neurons, and that this process is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that this process is dependent on the release of aggregates from the dying neurons. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that the internalization of aggregates by neurons is a key element of spreading and disease progression. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is increasingly recognized, but the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats, which is highly immunologically privileged for microbial community residence. This protein inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic diseases. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for energy and building blocks. We show that serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target that can be exploited to kill cancer cells. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in cancer cells and normal cells. We also show that cancer cells are uniquely dependent upon glycine import, and thus SHMT inhibition. These findings suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may explain the heterogeneous nature of the disease and the presence of a variety of inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. This also suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants were aquatic and terrestrial plants that reproduced below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolution of DNA viruses in particular has been difficult to study. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The results also have implications for the evolution of human populations and the spread of pathogens. This study is also the first to show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study is a step toward understanding the evolution of viruses and the evolution of humans.

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the hypothesis that the climate system is warming, and the rate of warming and the rate of sea level rise are both accelerating. The acceleration is not explained by changes in ocean mass, and it is not explained by changes in the thermal expansion and heat capacity of the oceans. The acceleration is consistent with the hypothesis that it is caused by the melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets and the melting of mountain glaciers.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a defining enzyme intermediate. This approach is able to identify the protonation states of ionizable sites, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters, and the tautomeric states of amino acid side chains. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this analysis is used to understand the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, and why the substrate indole is able to react, while the isostere benzimidazole does not. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of enzyme intermediates. This approach is expected to be broadly applicable to a wide range of enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria is a critical determinant of the stability of the mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the host is active and the bacteria are producing light. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbiota. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the evolution of animal-microbe interactions.

The suspension rate in US schools is 10 times higher than it was in 1992. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this mindset can be sustained. It also shows that this mindset can be taught to students, and that it can be sustained over time. Finally, it shows that a brief, online intervention can reduce suspensions by half. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and transcriptional lesion bypass routes. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop) that is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must be cleaved sequentially by two cell-surface proteases to enter cells, but the requirement for sequential proteolysis has not been characterized in detail. We found that the first cleavage step is required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This requirement for sequential proteolysis is significant because it expands virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings also suggest that the first cleavage step may be a target for antiviral therapy.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of global disease burden. The food choices people make are a key part of the solution. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can have a significant impact on sales. This is a simple and scalable way to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available, and therefore the health and environmental benefits they provide.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to analyze the surfaceome of a cell line stably expressing any of six oncogenes, and found that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is complicated by the rapid evolution of the virus, which has led to the emergence of variants that are resistant to neutralization by antibodies and vaccines. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a promising target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We show that ORF8 is a dimeric protein that can form a unique dimeric structure, which may be important for immune evasion. This structure provides a foundation for the development of vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying hypoxia-induced edema and suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of this condition. This study also provides a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying hypoxia-induced edema and suggests that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in a dataset, given that we have chosen which associations to look for. This is a difficult problem, but we describe some recent new developments that can help. The goal is to make statistical inference more robust to the fact that we have chosen which associations to look for.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)
We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentors, and demonstrate that they are essential for the development of a specific subset of cells in the body of the zebrafish.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin resistance has been well established, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function, resulting in glucose intolerance. Mechanistically, STING is required for β-cell function through the regulation of Pax6. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of STING in β-cell dysfunction and suggest a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are packaged into virions by a selective mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. The molecular details of this mechanism are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerosis are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. These findings may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the United States, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, increasing the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. This expansion is largely due to the expansion of the human-caused fire niche, which is driven by human actions to reduce fire risk and the expansion of human populations and development into areas that historically burned infrequently.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. Our results provide insights into the potential impact of antiviral treatment on the course of ZIKV infection. These insights can be used to guide the design of antiviral treatment strategies. Coral bleaching is a natural phenomenon that occurs when the coral host loses its symbiotic zooxanthellae, a single-celled algae that provide corals with a range of essential nutrients. However, in the face of climate change, bleaching events are becoming more frequent and more severe, threatening the survival of coral reefs worldwide. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a direct consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in the face of climate change. This may ultimately help us to protect coral reefs in the future.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the potential of JNK inhibition as a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression correlates with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and chemotherapy is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in Quaternary science. The onset of deglaciation is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this hypothesis has been difficult to test. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the onset of deglaciation, plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn likely caused a rapid climate response. This finding provides a unique test case for the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the last deglaciation and may have important implications for the timing of the next glaciation. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, providing food, livelihoods, and recreation to hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts, and their importance is difficult to assess because of the difficulty of quantifying catches. Here, we present a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that freshwater fisheries are particularly important in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce, and that the most productive rivers are also the most degraded. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective conservation and management strategies for inland fisheries, and to identify the most vulnerable populations that depend on these resources.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury, and the mechanisms that control this loss of regenerative capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has implications for understanding the mechanisms that control the loss of regenerative capacity in the adult mammalian CNS and for developing strategies to promote regeneration in the nervous system after injury.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key determinant of the structure of the genome. However, the spatial pattern of recombination is poorly understood. Here, we describe the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant, which is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic pattern of activity. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the large number of networks that are activated during rest. We used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the dominant RSN in healthy subjects, and to demonstrate that this network is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also showed that the dominant RSN is associated with reduced network function, and that this association is preserved in the presence of disease-related cognitive impairment. These results provide a framework for the interpretation of RSN studies, and suggest that metabolic imaging may be a useful tool for the study of brain function in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. The 5′ cap structure is also found on a subset of RNAs that are not translated, including some RNAs that are involved in RNA processing. We show that a third class of RNAs, 5′ NAD-RNAs, are also found on subsets of mRNAs. These results suggest that the 5′ NAD-RNA cap structure may have a role in regulating translation of specific classes of mRNA.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These loci are associated with glycemia, and high glucose induced similar persistent hypomethylation at one of them in cultured monocytes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be used as biomarkers of the effects of diabetes therapy. This may lead to the development of epigenetic therapies for diabetes.

The role of a protein in cancer is determined by its expression level, function, and interaction with other proteins. We have identified a protein, called Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), which is expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. We have shown that FSIP1 is involved in the regulation of autophagy and AMPK signaling, which are both important in the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs. Our findings may aid in the design of therapies for TNBC patients. (TNBC is a subtype of breast cancer that lacks estrogen and progesterone receptors and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.) (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the presence of psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The production of volatile compounds is a major component of the ripening process in many fruits, including tomato. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of a large number of these compounds in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a precursor to produce a wide range of nitrogenous volatile compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biochemistry of tomato fruit ripening and flavor. It also provides a model for the study of the biosynthesis of other classes of compounds in plants. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is altered by global warming. As temperatures increase, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance of species. First, more diverse communities had a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enabled them to maintain productivity as temperatures shifted from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to examine the organization of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are organized in a distinct manner from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings suggest that grid cells may have a unique functional role in the formation of navigation maps. This work provides a roadmap for future studies of the organization of navigation maps in MEC. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the evolution of flowering in plants. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and with the degeneration of striatonigral fibers, which project from the substantia nigra to the striatum. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of striatonigral fibers that originate in striosomes, the dopamine-synthesizing cells of the substantia nigra. These fibers form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing neurons and also project to the striatum. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system and are likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets are a novel system of neurons and fibers that may be important to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are often told that we should “click” with someone, but how do we know when we do? We conducted a series of experiments to understand the neural and behavioral mechanisms of the “click.” We found that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust predictor of how connected we feel to them. We also found that the speed with which we respond to others is used by others to assess the quality of our relationship with others. Together, these findings suggest that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate and are characterized by the presence of specialized Ca2+ release units, the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), and a unique electrical architecture. The SR Ca2+ release units are the sites of Ca2+ oscillations that are essential for the generation of action potentials in SANCs. However, the mechanisms that regulate SR Ca2+ release and the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and regulates SR Ca2+ release and electrical events in SANCs. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense has been debated. Here, we show that Si enhances resistance against insect herbivory in rice by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. We demonstrate that Si priming of JA signaling involves the promotion of JA accumulation and the activation of JA-responsive defense genes. Additionally, we show that Si priming of JA signaling is mediated by JA and is dependent on the expression of two key genes in the JA biosynthesis and perception pathways, allene oxide synthase and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in murine macrophages and that it is essential for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the sustained activation of neurons. However, alternative mechanisms have been proposed, including the facilitation of synaptic transmission. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNAi molecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures and show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of plant biotechnology.

The impact of nutrient loading on the quality and health of coastal ecosystems is well documented, but the relative importance of point and nonpoint sources of nutrients is less clear. We show that the majority of nutrient loads to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are delivered by small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which have the potential to fuel algal blooms in nearshore areas. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies, where the majority of nutrient loads are delivered by small tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a system of particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the potential energy.

The mechanisms by which antibodies disrupt the function of the NMDA receptor, a major excitatory receptor in the brain, are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies can change the intrinsic connections of the brain and alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the presence of a critical threshold. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures. This work also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other neuropsychiatric disorders on the brain’s intrinsic dynamics. This framework may be useful for the design of therapeutic interventions. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the role of organic matter in the Earth system. This work also highlights the importance of organic matter in the Earth system and the need to consider the role of organic matter in the history of abrupt climate change.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the use of sustainability certification is one of the main ways that companies and countries are attempting to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. Here, we show that certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the impact is small and limited to plantations that are already deforested. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations are necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the movement of vesicles from the trans Golgi network to the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we show that the number of sexes in a species is determined by the number of interacting sex determination alleles, and that the number of sexes can be increased by the acquisition of new sex determination alleles. These results have implications for the evolution of sex determination and the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of lipid-soluble reactive oxygen species (ROS)-generating products of the lipofuscin biosynthetic pathway. These products, collectively known as lipofuscinoids, are degraded by the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a cell type that is also challenged by the accumulation of the lipid-soluble ROS-generating products of the vitamin A biosynthetic pathway, collectively known as bisretinoids. We show that the intracellular levels of iron (Fe) impact the degradation of bisretinoids and the viability of photoreceptor cells. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a disease characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscinoids. They also suggest that Fe may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of retinal diseases. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of predatory specialization in the marine cnidarian siphonophores is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional innovations in separate structures dedicated to prey capture. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the distinctive features of the hand that are shared with Neandertals is still debated. Here we report the discovery of a third metacarpal styloid process in a 1.42-Myr-old hominin from Kenya. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand and suggests that the distinctive hand morphology of Neandertals and modern humans arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like traits. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for energy and building blocks. We show that serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target that can be exploited to kill cancer cells. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in cancer cells and normal cells. We also show that cancer cells are uniquely dependent upon glycine import, and thus SHMT inhibition. These findings suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition as well as from the consequences of an unhealthy diet. This study shows that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets, which are a key component of a healthy diet. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets as well as their conservation and environmental benefits.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but the increase in vehicle weight has also led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. We show that the increase in subsoil compaction has been so severe that it now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
